messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Re: Japanese Sword Terms Dictionary
messages.msgSnippet: Mutsu is from alternative numbering system for six. Hitotsu, futatsu, mitsu or 1, 2 and 3. These numbers are used for general counting and when you don t know
messages.messageBody:
Mutsu is from alternative numbering system for six. Hitotsu, futatsu, mitsu
or 1, 2 and 3. These numbers are used for general counting and when you
don't know the usual counting word. For example, one block of tofu is tofu
itcho. The Dictionary of Sword Terms I mentioned has all the fittings terms
as well.



Gordon

From: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com [mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com] On

six, yes? John

messages.subject: Re: Japanese Sword Terms Dictionary
messages.msgSnippet: Hello Elliott, I beleive Kajihara-sensei s Nihonto Yogo Jiten: Swords of Japan, A Visual Glossary (1989) may have the type of information you are looking for.
messages.messageBody:
Hello Elliott,

I beleive Kajihara-sensei's Nihonto Yogo Jiten: Swords of Japan, A
Visual Glossary (1989) may have the type of information you are
looking for. There is the Japanese text and a separate English
translation. I can't say for sure as we are out of stock. Perhaps
someone on the list can confirm that your term is in there.

Michael
http://satcho.com

messages.messageBody:
Gordon & all,

Is there a 'Dictionary of Japanese Tsuba/Tosogu Terms' available
somewhere? Do these dictionary's show the Kanji for the word being
looked up? AFU's and Richard's glossary's are excellant for showing the
Kanji.

I am looking for the kanji for mussomokko-gata. I believe this is 8-
sided shaped tsuba. I don't know for sure.

Just asking.

Elliott

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Nikuoki
messages.msgSnippet: Hi John, As I said, I do not use hamaguri-ba, so I looked it up in the Japanese Sword Terms Dictionary by Mr. Kajihara, and, as he states, When there is ample
messages.messageBody:
Hi John,

As I said, I do not use hamaguri-ba, so I looked it up in the Japanese Sword Terms
Dictionary by Mr. Kajihara, and, as he states, "When there is ample hira-niku,
because this shape looks like a clam shell, this term is used." In other words, if
there is ample niku between the shinogi and the cutting edge then hamaguri-ba is
used and used to mean the same thing as ample hira-niku or ample niku-oki. This
is not my definition because I never used this term nor heard it used in Japan.

Gordon

messages.subject: Re: Nikuoki
messages.msgSnippet: I second you on that Gordon. Never used the term either. Niku used frequently to describe a robust blade showing a more beefier blade from the shinogi down
messages.messageBody:
I second you on that Gordon. Never used the term either. Niku used
frequently to describe a robust blade showing a more 'beefier' blade
from the shinogi down to the ha and comes up mostly when refering to
how much metal appears to have been lost by polishing as compared to
the nakago. I do not think hamaguriba can be used quite the same way,
yes??? John

kanji for nakago
> in comparison to the NBTHK.

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Nikuoki
messages.msgSnippet: Oh, I forgot to add that I have never used the term hamaguri-ba, which is why I looked it up. Hiraniku or nikuoki are the terms I use. I have noticed that
messages.messageBody:
Oh,

I forgot to add that I have never used the term hamaguri-ba, which is why I looked
it up. Hiraniku or nikuoki are the terms I use. I have noticed that NBTHK people
use different terms from NTHK people in Japan, particularly with written work.
Different kanji are also used, for example the NTHK uses different kanji for nakago
in comparison to the NBTHK.

Gordon

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Nikuoki
messages.msgSnippet: Hi John, I was a bit slow in answering Barry, but my answer is based on the entry in the Nihontô Yogo Jiten or Dictionary of Sword Terms. It gives
messages.messageBody:
Hi John,

I was a bit slow in answering Barry, but my answer is based on the entry in the
Nihontô Yogo Jiten or Dictionary of Sword Terms. It gives hamaguri-ba as an
equivalent to ample nikuoki. The reference is to a cherry stone clam or hamaguri,
and means that the hiraji swells like a clam shell. One of my favorite things is to
take Japanese colleagues to Legal Seafood in Boston and turn them on to raw
cherry stones. Japanese don't eat raw clams, so it is always interesting to see their
faces light up when they try them for the first time.

Gordon

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Nikuoki
messages.msgSnippet: Deshou. Yes, hamaguri-ba is the same as ample nikuoki. Gordon
messages.messageBody:
Deshou. Yes, hamaguri-ba is the same as ample nikuoki.

Gordon

messages.subject: Re: Nikuoki
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Barry, Hamaguriba is a particular type of sword construction that has a thicker or meatier blade that has a more wedging action to a cut, as I
messages.messageBody:
Hi Barry, Hamaguriba is a particular type of sword construction that
has a 'thicker' or 'meatier' blade that has a more wedging action to
a cut, as I understand it. Niku, esp. in the hiraji, can refer to
presence or lack of this in blade construction but is commonly used
to describe the effects of polishing whereas hamaguriba does not. At
least this is how I've used the term conversationally, maybe
incorrectly, with others and the intent is generally understood. John

Milt,

Blades that haven't been polished to death. All the early stuff has or had great
nikuoki. When you see a Kamakura period blade that was dedicated to a shrine
during the Kamakura period, then you know what it looks like.

Gordon
.

Milt you over clean everything you touch and that is why the waxy shiny surface LOL.

John

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Nikuoki
messages.msgSnippet: Jim et al, From some of my sharing of pieces with you, a lot of the tsuba from the 1800-1850 have that glassy type look.  If I remember correctly, the plates
messages.messageBody:
Jim et al,

From some of my sharing of pieces with you, a lot of the tsuba from the 1800-1850 have that glassy type look. If I remember correctly, the plates of a lot of these tsuba are overdone trying to mimic older pieces but the metal is different and that glassy type look is a clue, the rust/patination have a specific look that the original tsuba don't have. Not sure if I am describing it totally correct, so if you could state it better or correct what I am trying to say, it would be helpful to a lot of us, since it seems there are a lot of tsuba from this period out there. Thanks
Ken

P.S. not to encourage any more beer talk, but what Milt doesn't realize is that every sword papering group is drinking on Milt's dime. When he submits his pieces, they just give him a quick answer and then drink his fees (this is only for Milt) and not particular to anyone group. LOL.

----- Original Message ----
From: Jim Gilbert <jggilbert@...>
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Thursday, February 28, 2008 9:30:23 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Nikuoki

OK, enough chitchat about beer.

Milt,
The brass inlay groups you mention did not use any sort of clear coat. If present, that would be a recent addition, probably to try to "improve" the surface of a rusty plate and/or to try to hold loose inlay in place. I doubt that it's lacquer - it's probably something modern. I'd consider it a serious condition problem. I have seen that occasionally on Onin tsuba, which do tend to have very dry, rusty plates that are very difficult to restore properly.

Agreed that nikuoki is a different term when used around swords.

Jim

----- Original Message -----
From: MuramasaIII@ aol.com
To: nihontostudy@ yahoogroups. com
Sent: Thursday, February 28, 2008 9:15 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Nikuoki

what's Asahi ? The watery beer from Land of the gods ?
By the way, I notice those Yoshiro/Onin/ Heianjo tsuba usually have what
appeared to be a " clear " sheen over the whole surface ( over the brass and iron
), what is that ? Some sort of clear lacquer ?

The curious wants to know........ ........

In a message dated 2/28/2008 8:07:21 P.M. Central Standard Time,
jggilbert@EARTHLINK .NET writes:

Unfortunately I'd say that Asahi lacks nikuoki as well.

Jim

messages.msgSnippet: I have to agree, Asahi is not so good . Saporo is my choice of Japanese beer. But then again, I would just as soon drink Tequila! Jim, you refered to nikuoki
messages.messageBody:
I have to agree, Asahi is 'not so good'. Saporo is my choice of
Japanese beer. But then again, I would just as soon drink Tequila!

Jim, you refered to nikuoki in your Q & A page while talking about
Soten. And thanks for clarifying the term.

Gordon, what does it define in relation to swords? Niku means 'meat'
doesn't it?

Thanks all, Elliott

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Nikuoki
messages.msgSnippet: OK, enough chitchat about beer. Milt, The brass inlay groups you mention did not use any sort of clear coat.  If present, that would be a recent addition,
messages.messageBody:
OK, enough chitchat about beer.

Milt,
The brass inlay groups you mention did not use any sort of clear coat. If present, that would be a recent addition, probably to try to "improve" the surface of a rusty plate and/or to try to hold loose inlay in place. I doubt that it's lacquer - it's probably something modern. I'd consider it a serious condition problem. I have seen that occasionally on Onin tsuba, which do tend to have very dry, rusty plates that are very difficult to restore properly.

Agreed that nikuoki is a different term when used around swords.

Jim

), what is that ? Some sort of clear lacquer ?

The curious wants to know................

Agreed, Asahi sucks. Try Ebisu. Also, note that nikuoki has a different meaning in

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Nikuoki
messages.msgSnippet: Elliot, Did I really say that?  Nikuoki is the subtle variation in the treatment of the surface of a tsuba, particularly through hammer work.  Nikuoki is a
messages.messageBody:
Elliot,

Did I really say that? Nikuoki is the subtle variation in the treatment of the surface of a tsuba, particularly through hammer work. Nikuoki is a quality found in a good Owari or Kanayama tsuba, for example. It's definitely not present in something like Soten work. While I am not at all a fan of Soten tsuba, it wouldn't have been entirely fair of me to criticize it for inferior nikuoki since that's not at all what that type of work is about, but rather picturesque 3-D carving and inlay.

Unfortunately I'd say that Asahi lacks nikuoki as well.

Jim

is inferior". What is nikuoki?

Thanks, Elliott

Now please continue your conversation about beer, it's making me
thirsty for Asahi.
